Author: jl777c#5810
Content: yes, W.6 and W.12 are the only ones you should see

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: if so, the adaptivepow=6 logic is working

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: and should avoid the large back and forth

Author: Mihailo#5902
Content: BTW, what is the logic behined aPoW params, what 1,2,3,4,5,6,7 means

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: 1 is all the windows active

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: 2 is not really used, legacy for a totally different method

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: 3 means all the filters and i guess works the same as 1

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: 4 means all the filter other than W.1

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: 5 is all but W.1 and W.2

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: 6 is all but W.1, W.2 and W.3

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: 7 is only W.12

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: there are 5 windows 1, 2, 3, 6, 12 blocks wide

Author: Mihailo#5902
Content: And I suppose those windows means how often it will adjust difficulty

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: if there is a variance that indicates an increased hashrate, it forces the blocktime to be slower

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: the DAA is adjusting every second, within the block, once a W.x is triggered

Author: Mihailo#5902
Content: Aha, and window is how far to look when adjusting?

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: no

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: the window is a detection width

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: so if in the last 1, 2, 3, 6, or 12 blocks it is solved significantly faster than expected, then it goes into adaptive mode

Author: Mihailo#5902
Content: Aha, ok. Similair to what I thought

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: once it starts the adaptive mode, it stays active for 20, 30, 40, or 50 blocks or until the time deficit is made up

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: so it boosts the diff up to correspond with what it things the actual hashrate is

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: then if after 10 minutes there is no block, it starts making it easier to cover the case where it was too aggressive

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: so it isnt perfect, but over time the average blocktime ends up where it should be

Author: Mihailo#5902
Content: üëç

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: certainly if it kicks in, the blocktimes will become much less consistent for a while but that is the cost for being able to recover from a billion-fold diff stranding
